awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Developing an Equity-Driven, Collaborative, Inquiry-Based Online Computer Science Option for Credit Recovery and Incarcerated Youth in Urban Settings
awd_abstract_narration:
The Learning Partnership in collaboration with Education Development Center (EDC), the Chicago Public School District (CPS) and the Chicago Alliance for Equity in Computer Science (CAFECS), proposes to address a significant and urgent need for CPS to provide an online version of the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) program. ECS is designed to introduce students to the breadth of the field of computer science through an exploration of engaging and accessible topics. Its success in CPS led CPS to become the first major city to enact a high school computer science (CS) graduation requirement. An implication of that policy is that students who fail their CS class will need to make it up in order to graduate. This proposed work will use a Researcher Practitioner Partnership (RPP) approach to begin the development of an online version of ECS that can be used for credit recovery.

An analysis of student ECS course failure shows that the typical CPS student who will need to recover the CS credit is most likely to be a 10th, 11th or 12th grade Hispanic or African American male student with low academic performance and relatively high rates of absences. The very strong ECS focus on equitable and culturally relevant approaches to pedagogy, the strong partnership that already exists between the Learning Partnership, CPS, and CAFECS, the paucity of existing research on how to support online credit recovery, and the urgency of developing credit recovery options for current students, all combine to provide a unique opportunity to develop an online version of ECS that builds on our knowledge of how best to support for struggling, urban CS students.

The lack of existing research on credit recovery represents a significant risk. However, if the project team is successful, this model has the potential for high reward: a high-quality option for students seeking credit recovery, as well as those who are incarcerated or homeless, or otherwise struggle to have an equitable experience to that of their peers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
From SY19-SY21, in collaboration with the Chicago Alliance for Equity in Computer Science (CAF?CS), the Chicago Public Schools (CPS) Office of Computer Science (OCS) developed (SY19) and ran (SY20-21) both hybrid and fully remote computer science credit recovery programs. 

The successful piloting of the hybrid credit recovery course produced findings that should inform future credit recovery offerings for Computer Science (CS) and other content areas in CPS. Five recommendations for credit recovery courses are listed below.

(1) Curriculum Design: Select credit recovery curricula that foster student engagement and equitable, supportive classroom cultures. The guiding philosophy and modes of instruction embedded in the hybrid credit recovery course incorporate culturally and linguistically responsive instruction, inquiry-based and experiential learning, collaborative classroom cultures, and social/emotional learning. These pedagogical anchors were built into the hybrid course and the accompanying professional development (PD) program for credit recovery teachers. 


(2) Teacher Recruitment: Recruit teachers for credit recovery who have experience teaching the selected curricula and a deep understanding of the types of instructional practices that benefit reluctant and struggling learners. To provide students with a high quality hybrid CS credit recovery experience, OCS engaged experienced teachers as instructors and located the in-person portions of the class at school sites easily accessible by public transport to student populations who needed to recover credit. 


(3) Teacher PD: Provide PD focused on effective teaching practices for credit recovery in order to foster student engagement and equitable, supportive classroom cultures. Prior to teaching the hybrid course for credit recovery, teachers were required to complete a PD that outlined the course design and guiding philosophy. This PD, additionally, provided a structured opportunity for teachers to reflect on the needs of students who had already failed the CS course and discuss effective strategies for struggling and reluctant learners. For example, a major emphasis of the PD (and written guidance) for hybrid credit recovery teachers was the need to create high-touch experiences and systems of support for all students. The PD also allowed the course developers to model the type of culture-building activities that were central to the design.


(4) Teacher Support: Cultivate professional learning through ongoing support and networking opportunities for credit recovery teachers, in the form of virtual learning communities.  The credit recovery teachers were provided with ongoing support by district personnel and the course developers during the piloting of the hybrid course. This support included weekly check-in meetings, frequent email communication, and the creation of a virtual department (a learning community that met via Google Meet and Google Chat). Teacher feedback gathered during the pilot provided evidence that such supports were valued. 


(5) Hybrid Modality: Offer students flexibility through hybrid modes of instruction that couple "anytime, anywhere" learning with high touch, personalized supports that build interpersonal relationships and promote student agency in their own learning. This is of particular benefit to students who have work or other obligations during the summer. The hybrid course was conceived as a student-centered, equity-focused option for high schoolers who need to recover CS credit. An analysis of the schools offering in-person credit recovery in the year prior to the grant revealed that a computer science course was not available within two miles of the high school where most students needed one (see Figure 1). The chosen hybrid design??some in-person lessons and some remote lessons??afforded CPS students greater access and flexibility while allowing for ongoing interpersonal support from a teacher. Moreover, the design integrated pedagogical principles and practices aimed at better meeting the needs of students who had already failed a previous attempt at the course. The developers established a collaborative, social experience that fosters inquiry-based learning and equity-based teaching practices. 

Intellectual Merit

Interview and focus group data gathered from teachers and students during the piloting of the hybrid/online course generated evidence to support what the developers had originally hypothesized about the need to provide adequate structures and support for struggling and reluctant learners. Specifically, teacher and student feedback revealed that remote instruction for credit recovery is more effective when it involves synchronous, supportive interactions and time-dependent tasks with accountability (not asynchronous, self-paced instruction). In addition to the hybrid/remote curriculum and research results, the project generated a framework and set of recommendations for credit recovery in CPS to support implementation in future years.

Broader Impacts

Over the course of SY20 and SY21, 253 students participated in CS credit recovery courses coordinated by OCS. Of the grades earned in these courses, 94% were a D or higher (27% A, 27% B, 19% C, 20% D), allowing students to redeem their credit. The program was designed from the start to be delivered in a hybrid modality??some activities in-person or synchronous online, some activities remote and asynchronous??which proved very helpful with the transition to remote learning due to the COVID-19 pandemic.


Last Modified: 02/01/2022
Modified by: Steven M Mcgee

Image
  • Figure 1: Map showing all CPS HS (black dots). Color coding indicates distance from HS offering CS credit recovery in SY19.
    Catherine McGee
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
